title: Oxygen - ideal gas law and KMT

content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student investigates gas behavior using a rigid cylinder with a movable piston of negligible mass, as shown in the diagram above. The cylinder contains <math alttext="0.325 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.325</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> mol</mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>of <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>.

(a) The cylinder has a volume of <math alttext="7.95 liters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.95</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> L</mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="1.00 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> atm</mtext></math>. Calculate the density of the <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, in <math alttext="grams per liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>g</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, under these conditions.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student investigates gas behavior using a rigid cylinder with a movable piston of negligible mass, as shown in the diagram above. The cylinder contains <math alttext="0.325 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.325</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> mol</mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>of <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>.

(a) The cylinder has a volume of <math alttext="7.95 liters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.95</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> L</mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="1.00 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> atm</mtext></math>. Calculate the density of the <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, in <math alttext="grams per liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>g</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, under these conditions.

(b) Attempting to change the density of the <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student opens the valve on the side of the cylinder, pushes down on the piston to release some of the gas, and closes the valve again. The temperature of the gas remains constant at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Will this action change the density of the gas remaining in the cylinder? Justify your answer.

(c) The student tries to change the density of the <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> by cooling the cylinder to <math alttext="negative 55 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>−</mo><mn>55</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>, which causes the volume of the gas to decrease. Using principles of kinetic molecular theory, explain why the volume of the <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases when the temperature decreases to <math alttext="negative 55 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>−</mo><mn>55</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>.

(d) The student further cools the cylinder to <math alttext="negative 180 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>−</mo><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math> and observes that the measured volume of the <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is substantially smaller than the volume that is calculated using the ideal gas law. Assume all equipment is functioning properly. Explain why the measured volume of the <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is smaller than the calculated volume. (The boiling point of <math alttext="O 2, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="negative 183 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>−</mo><mn>183</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>.)

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
